BREXIT is such an all-consuming process for the Britishat once a drama, a muddle and a messthat it is easy to forget that it is part of something bigger: a crisis of liberalism in the west. A growing number of countries have had their own equivalents of Brexit: Donald Trumps victory over Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election; the election of a populist government in Italy; the Catalan revolt in Spain; the rise of populist authoritarians in Russia, Hungary, Poland and, to some extent, India; the simmering rage against what Viktor Orban calls liberal blah blah in the intellectual dark-web. The list will be a lot longer by the time Brexit has been completed.
